Line 333: Line 333:
==Bahraini uprising==
==Bahraini uprising==
{{main|2011 Bahraini uprising}}
{{main|2011 Bahraini uprising}}
  +
[[File:252988 190793104306448 170666489652443 525903 1116403 n.jpg|thumb|250px|]]
[[File:Pearl Monument Leveled.jpg|thumb|250px|On the morning of 18 March 2011, after dispersing all protesters with the help of the Saudi military, the government [[Pearl Roundabout#Demolition|tore down the Pearl Monument]], the rallying point for protests against it.]]
[[File:Pearl Monument Leveled.jpg|thumb|250px|On the morning of 18 March 2011, after dispersing all protesters with the help of the Saudi military, the government [[Pearl Roundabout#Demolition|tore down the Pearl Monument]], the rallying point for protests against it.]]
The 2011 protests in [[Bahrain]] were initially aimed at achieving greater [[political freedom]] and respect for [[human rights in Bahrain|human rights]], and were not intended to threaten the monarchy.<ref name="JazeeraBah14Feb">{{Cite news|title=Clashes mark Bahrain 'Day of Rage'|date=14 February 2011|publisher=[[Al-Jazeera English]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011214925802473.html|accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> Lingering frustration among the Shiite majority with being ruled by the Sunni government was a major root cause, but the protests in Tunisia and Egypt are cited as the inspiration for the demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news|title=wo Protesters Dead as Bahrain Declares State of Emergency|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/16/world/middleeast/16bahrain.html?scp=43&sq=bahrain%20majority&st=cse|date=15 March 2011|accessdate=11 May 2011|work=The New York Times|first=Ethan|last=Bronner}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|titleForces Rout Protesters From Bahrain Square|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/17/world/middleeast/17bahrain.html?scp=1&sq=bahrain%20majority&st=cse|date=16 March 2011|accessdate=11 May 2011|work=The New York Times|first=Ethan|last=Bronner|title=Bahrain Troops Oust Protesters From Square}}</ref> The protests began in Bahrain on 14 February<ref name="JazeeraBah14Feb"/> and were largely peaceful, until a raid by police on the night of 17 February against protestors sleeping at the [[Pearl Roundabout]] in [[Manama]], in which police killed three protestors.<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb">{{Cite news|first=|last=|pages=|language=|title=Clashes rock Bahraini capital|date=2011-02|publisher=Al Jazeera English |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121714223324820.html |accessdate=17 February 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wZPVZfFG|archivedate=17 February 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="bbc231injured">{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12490286|title=Bahrain protests: Police break up Pearl Square crowd|author=[[BBC]]|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=17 February 2011|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Following the deadly raid, the protestors' aims expanded to a call for the end of the [[King of Bahrain|monarchy]].<ref name="guard_downwiththeking">{{Cite news|first=|last=|pages=|language=|title=Bahrain mourners call for end to monarchy |date=18 February 2011 |publisher=The Guardian/[[Associated Press|AP]] |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/18/bahrain-mourners-call-downnfall-monarchy|accessdate=18 February 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5waOzlomm |archivedate=18 February 2011 |deadurl=no |location=London}}</ref>
The 2011 protests in [[Bahrain]] were initially aimed at achieving greater [[political freedom]] and respect for [[human rights in Bahrain|human rights]], and were not intended to threaten the Times|first=Ethan|last=Bronner|title=Bahrain Troops Oust Protesters From Square}}</ref> The protests began in Bahrain on 14 February<ref name="JazeeraBah14Feb"/> and were largely peaceful, until a news|first=|last=|pages=|language=|title=Clashes rock Bahraini capital|date=2011-02|publisher=Al Jazeera English |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121714223324820.html |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/18/bahrain-mourners-call-downnfall-monarchy|accessdate=18 February 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5waOzlomm |archivedate=18 February 2011
